bestBHT.bht: The two Marys were not only witnesses to the crucifixion, but also carefully observed His burial. Their continuous action of beholding Him reflected the true nature of genuine love, remaining steadfast even in times of deep suffering and humiliation. Their presence and observation served as a poignant reminder of the gathering of Christian congregations, united through the death of Christ.

Henry Alford: That the same person is so called here, and Mary of James in the next verse, points to a difference of origin in the two accounts here, of the Crucifixion and Resurrection.
The mother of the Lord had in all probability previously departed.
St. Luke generalizes, and says, the women who came with Him from Galilee.
Albert Barnes: The affection of these pious females never forsook them, in all the trials and sufferings of their Lord.
Female love never forsook him, even in his deepest humiliation. This is the nature of true love; it is strongest in such scenes.
In scenes of poverty, want, affliction, and death, [true love] shows its genuineness.
Marvin Vincent: Beheld [εθεωρουν] . Imperfect tense. Were looking on meanwhile. The verb also implies steady and careful contemplation. They took careful note.
Philip Schaff: Beheld, lit., ‘were beholding,’ a continued action.
The original indicates that they came after the burial, entering without hesitation the garden of the rich councillor.
The company was a singular one, but a type of the Christian congregations collected together by the death of Christ.
Archibald T. Robertson: Beheld (εθεωρουν). Imperfect tense picturing the two Marys 'sitting over against the sepulchre' and watching in silence as the shadows fell upon all their hopes and dreams.
Apparently these two remained after the other women who had been beholding from afar the melancholy end had left and 'were watching the actions of Joseph and Nicodemus.'
It is evident that they constituted themselves a party of observation.
John Gill: Very likely they saw Joseph, and his men, take him down from the cross, and they followed him, and observed where he laid him...
...they were witnesses of his death, and of his burial...
...as they afterwards were of his resurrection from the dead.

bhtAttempts.bht: The two Marys mentioned in this verse were not only witnesses to the crucifixion of Jesus, but they also carefully observed His burial. Despite the sadness and despair that must have filled their hearts, these women remained steadfast, faithfully watching over Jesus. Their love for Him never wavered, demonstrating the true nature of genuine love that is strongest in times of deep suffering and humiliation. Their continuous action of beholding and their decision to enter the garden of the rich councillor after the burial show their dedication and devotion. In a way, their presence and observation foreshadow the gathering of Christian congregations that would come together through the death of Christ.

The two Marys in this passage were able to intimately witness the crucifixion, burial, and ultimately, resurrection of Jesus. They diligently observed and took careful note of the events unfolding before them, their love and dedication to Him unwavering. Their continuous action of beholding Him reflects the true nature of genuine love, which remains steadfast even in times of deep humiliation and suffering. Their presence and observation serve as a poignant reminder of the gathering of Christian congregations, united by the death of Christ.

The two Marys in this account were witnesses to the crucifixion, burial, and resurrection of Jesus. They steadfastly beheld the events with careful contemplation, their love for Him never diminishing even in times of deep suffering and humiliation. Their continuous observation and presence demonstrate the true nature of genuine love, remaining firm amidst trials and adversity. In a sense, their faithful witness anticipates the formation of Christian congregations, united through the death of Christ.

The two Marys were not only witnesses to the crucifixion, but also carefully observed His burial. Despite despair, they faithfully watched over Jesus. Their love never forsook Him, even in deepest humiliation. This true love is strongest in scenes of poverty, want, affliction, and death. Their continuous action of beholding and their decision to enter the garden of the rich councillor show their dedication. In a way, their presence and observation foreshadow the Christian congregations coming together through the death of Christ.

The two Marys were not only witnesses to the crucifixion, but also carefully observed His burial. Their continuous action of beholding Him reflected the true nature of genuine love, remaining steadfast even in times of deep suffering and humiliation. Their presence and observation served as a poignant reminder of the gathering of Christian congregations, united through the death of Christ.
